string.__text: Tartrazine is a synthetic yellow dye belonging to the azo dye group. It is chemically produced from azobenzene.\10\10Notably, this dye is believed to cause hyperactivity and attention deficit disorders in children when combined with sodium benzoate (E211). Foods containing this additive are required by the European Union to be marked with the statement, \"May have an adverse effect on activity and attention in children.\" However, in its 2008 evaluation, the EFSA toned down the conclusions of the most incriminating study, indicating that there was no evidence of a cause-and-effect relationship. The results of the study nonetheless show a real impact on certain populations of individuals with sensitivities to food additives in general or to food dyes specifically. Moreover, recent studies suggest that artificial coloring is not the main cause of attention deficit disorder with or without hyperactivity (ADHD), but they may contribute to it significantly in some cases (Arnold et al., 2012). \10\10Tartrazine is also believed to cause hypersensitivity and intolerance reactions (urticaria, eczema, etc.). The European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) notes that tartrazine appears to cause intolerance reactions in individuals with sensitivities to additives in general or to dyes specifically, and that these individuals may react to the dye at doses within the ADI (Acceptable Daily Intake) range.\10\10Finally, some recent studies implicate tartrazine in other potential effects. According to an animal study, tartrazine may cause neurotoxicity and learning and memory deficits at dose levels in excess of the ADI. Moreover, prolonged use of tartrazine may contribute to the development of some cancers.\10\10In the 2009 EFSA opinion, the panel notes that tartrazine specifications must be updated (sodium chloride and/or sodium sulfate levels, lead content), while other specifications are required (maximum aluminum level).\10

Tartrazine is believed to cause hyperactivity and attention deficit disorders in children when combined with sodium benzoate.\10\10It is also believed to cause hypersensitivity and intolerance reactions (urticaria, eczema, etc.), to cause neurotoxicity and learning and memory deficits, and to contribute to the development of some cancers.

Sunset yellow FCF is a synthetic yellow dye belonging to the family of azo dyes. It is chemically derived from azobenzene.\10\10This dye is believed to cause hyperactivity and deficit disorders in children when combined with sodium benzoate (E211). However, in its 2008 evaluation, EFSA toned down the conclusions of the most incriminating study, indicating that there was no evidence of a cause-and-effect relationship. The results of the study nonetheless show a real impact on certain populations of individuals with sensitivities to food additives in general or to food dyes in particular. In fact, the European Commission requires all foods containing this additive to display the following warning message: “May have an adverse effect on activity and attention in children.”\10\10Moreover, recent studies suggest that artificial food colors are not a major cause of attention deficit disorder per se, but may significantly affect children in some cases, regardless of whether they have attention deficit with or without hyperactivity (ADHD) (Arnold et al., 2012). \10\10Finally, a study conducted in 2012 indicates that Sunset Yellow PCF may also alter the functional responses of certain immune cells.

Sunset Yellow FCF is believed to cause hyperactivity and attention deficit disorders in children when combined with sodium benzoate.\10\10Sunset yellow FCF may also alter the functional responses of certain immune cells.

Cochineal extract is a natural red dye. It is derived from an insect, the cochineal (Dactylopius coccus costa). The body of the female insect is dried and then ground. Next, an extraction process is conducted on the ground matter to separate out the dyestuff.\10\10This dye is also called carmine due to its carminic acid content, the origin of its red color.\10\10Multiple studies have shown that cochineal extract has allergenic potential, primarily linked to insect proteins. The European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) thus acknowledges, in its 2015 re-evaluation, that residual proteins from the extraction process may trigger allergies (asthma attacks, urticaria, edema, etc.) in susceptible individuals. It recommends that manufacturers reduce residual protein content as much as possible by adding purification steps to the manufacturing process. \10\10The EFSA also supports labeling to inform consumers of the presence of this dye in products and the related risk of allergen exposure for susceptible individuals.\10\10Moreover, the EFSA recommends that this additive\'s specifications should be revised with regard to upper limits of metal content (arsenic, mercury, cadmium, and lead) to ensure that the additive is not a source of exposure.\10\10However, the EFSA dismisses concerns about risks of carcinogenicity, genotoxicity, or reproductive toxicity.

This additive is a natural dye derived from an insect. It can cause an allergic reaction, primarily related to insect proteins. \10\10According to the EFSA (2015), protein residue may cause an allergic reaction (asthma attacks, urticaria, edema, etc.) in susceptible individuals. The EFSA recommends that manufacturers reduce residual protein content as much as possible.\10

Allura Red is a synthetic red dye belonging to the family of azo dyes used in foodstuffs. It is produced chemically from azobenzene.\10\10As demonstrated in a study by McCann in 2007, Allura Red can cause hyperactivity and attention deficit disorders in children when combined with sodium benzoate (E211). In 2009, the EFSA (European Food Safety Authority) downplayed the results of this study by citing a lack of substantial evidence with regard to causality and mechanisms of action. In particular, it emphasized the fact that a combination of dyes were used in the McCann study, making it impossible to know if the effects were caused specifically by the Allura Red, by another dye, or by the combination. At any rate, all foods containing Allura Red must be labeled \"May have an adverse effect on activity and attention in children.\"\10\10Moreover, recent studies suggest that artificial dyes are not the main cause of attention deficit disorder with or without hyperactivity (ADHD), but that they may, in some cases, play a significant role (Arnold et al., 2012). \10\10Allura Red is also believed to cause allergic reactions (hives, eczema, etc.). According to the EFSA, Allura Red can cause allergic reactions in individuals who are usually sensitive to additives, and in particular, to dyes. These individuals may even react to the dye at doses that are less than the acceptable daily intake (ADI).

Allura Red is a synthetic red dye believed to cause hyperactivity and attention deficit disorders in children when combined with sodium benzoate.\10\10It is also believed to cause allergic reactions (hives, eczema, etc.).

Brilliant Blue FCF is a synthetic blue dye used in many food products.\10\10Recent studies suggest that artificial coloring is not the main cause of attention deficit disorder with or without hyperactivity (ADHD), but they may contribute to it significantly in some cases (Arnold et al., 2012). \10\10Moreover, a 2015 study conducted after the re-evaluation shows that it may have genotoxic (toxic to the genome) and cytotoxic (toxic to cells) potential.\10\10In 1984, the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) revised the ADI (Acceptable Daily Intake) to 10 mg per kg of body weight per day, based on new toxicity studies. The ADI had previously been set at 12.5 mg.\10\10Subsequently, in 2010, the EFSA again lowered the ADI, this time from 10 to 6 mg per kg of body weight per day. The EFSA concluded that the level of exposure is generally lower than the ADI, but that it may be exceeded in children whose intake is very high. However, the EFSA dismisses concerns about risks of carcinogenicity, genotoxicity, or reproductive toxicity.

Brilliant Blue FCF is a synthetic blue dye. It is believed to contribute to attention deficit disorder with or without hyperactivity (ADHD).\10\10It may also have genotoxic (toxic to the genome) and cytotoxic (toxic to cells) potential.

Amidon acétylé à acétate de vinyle

This color additive brings together under the same name (“caramel color”) 4 different classes of caramel coloring presenting different levels of health risk. Unlike European regulations which require that the type of caramel used by manufacturers be indicated on product labels, the US FDA (Food and Drug Administration) and Health Canada make no distinction between them: the same term is used to describe any class.\10\10The 4 classes of caramel coloring differ in their method of manufacture and composition:\10 \101. Caramel Color I (also called plain caramel, caustic caramel or E150a in Europe); this class is prepared by heating carbohydrates with or without acids or alkalis. Plain caramel is not harmful to human health.\10 \102. Caramel Color II (also called caustic sulfite caramel or E150b); this class is prepared by the controlled heat treatment of carbohydrates in the presence of sulfite compounds. Sulfites can cause allergies or intolerance reactions in some individuals.\10 \103. Caramel Color III (also called ammonia caramel or E150c); this class is prepared by the controlled heat treatment of carbohydrates with ammonium compounds. During the manufacturing process, two problematic compounds are formed which can be found in trace amounts in caramel at the conclusion of the production process:\10 \10• 4-MEI (4-methylimidazole): it has been classified as “possibly carcinogenic to humans” (group 2B) by the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) and listed as a carcinogen by California’s Proposition 65 law “Safe Drinking Water and Toxic Enforcement Act of 1986” (OEHHA, 2011). As a result, any product sold in California that contains 4-MEI concentrations corresponding to exposures that pose excess cancer risks (1 case per 100,000 exposed persons) and is set at 29 μg 4-MEI/day, has to carry a warning label. The FDA is currently reviewing all available data on the safety of 4-MEI to determine what, if any, regulatory action needs to be taken.\10 \10• THI (2-Acetyl-4(5)-tetrahydroxybutylimidazole): this component can be toxic to the immune system.\10 \104. Caramel Color IV (also called sulfite ammonia caramel or E150d); this class is prepared by heating carbohydrates with ammonium-containing and sulfite-containing compounds. During the manufacturing process, compounds suspected to be carcinogenic (4-MEI) are formed. Residue of this compound can be found in caramel at the end of the production process. Moreover, sulfites are used in the production of this color additive which may trigger allergies or intolerance reactions in some individuals.\10 \10Class III and Class IV caramel coloring are the most commonly used food color additives by volume.\10 \10“There is no requirement in FDA’s regulations that the ingredient statement on the label of foods that contain Class III or Class IV caramel coloring list the color additive by name or type. It is therefore not possible, unless voluntarily disclosed, to know based on the label if a food contains Class III or IV caramel coloring “confirms the FDA.

“Caramel color” consists of 4 types of caramel with different health risk levels. North-America regulations make no distinction between these classes and they’re all displayed under the same name.\10 \10During the manufacturing process of Class III & IV, potentially carcinogenic or immunotoxic compounds (4-MeI and THI) are formed which can be eventually found in trace amounts in this color additive.

Caramel coloring is an additive made by heating sugars in the presence of ammonium compounds. It is used to give products a brown/yellow color.\10\10During the manufacturing process, two problematic compounds are formed:\10\10• 4-MEI (4-methylimidazole), which the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) lists as a Class 2B substance (\"potentially carcinogenic to humans\"). This compound is also listed as a carcinogen by the State of California under Proposition 65, the Safe Drinking Water and Toxic Enforcement Act of 1986 (OEHHA, 2011).\10• THI (2-acetyl-5-tetrahydroxybutyl imidazole), a substance that may be toxic to the immune system.\10\10These compounds can be found in caramel at the conclusion of the production process. Current specifications indicate thresholds that are not to be exceeded.\10\10In its 2011 re-evaluation, the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) established a group ADI of 300 mg per kg of body weight per day for the 4 caramel colors (E150a, E150b, E150c, and E150d). It also specified a more restrictive ADI of 100 mg per kg of body weight per day for E150c, given new information regarding THI.\10\10In 2012, the EFSA concluded in a new evaluation that E150c food exposure may exceed the ADI in young children and adults whose intake is very high.\10\10The EFSA also requests studies to clarify some uncertainty surrounding the potential effects of THI on the immune system.\10\10Finally, in its 2011 re-evaluation, the EFSA noted that other constituents (such as 5-HMF and furan) may be present at levels that may be of concern and that specifications should include maximum levels for those constituents as well.

This additive is used to give products a brown/yellow color.\10\10During the manufacturing process, two problematic compounds are formed: 4-MEI (evaluated by the IARC as \"potentially carcinogenic to humans\") and THI (a substance that may be toxic to the immune system). These two compounds can be found in caramel at the conclusion of the production process.

Sulfite ammonia caramel is an additive made by heating sugars in the presence of ammonium and sulfite derivatives. It is used to give products a brown color.\10\10During the manufacturing process, two problematic compounds are formed: 4-MEI (4-methylimidazole). The International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) lists 4-MEI as a Class 2B substance (\"potentially carcinogenic to humans\"). This compound is also listed as a carcinogen by the State of California under Proposition 65, the Safe Drinking Water and Toxic Enforcement Act of 1986 (OEHHA, 2011).\10\10Residue of this compound can be found in caramel at the conclusion of the production process. Current specifications regarding the regulation of caramels indicate thresholds that are not to be exceeded.\10\10Moreover, sulfites are used in the production of this additive. These compounds may trigger allergies or intolerance reactions in some individuals. \10\10In its 2011 re-evaluation, the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) established a group ADI of 300 mg per kg of body weight per day for the 4 caramel colors (E150a, E150b, E150c, and E150d). \10\10Finally, in its 2011 re-evaluation, the EFSA noted that other constituents (such as 5-HMF and furan) may be present at levels that may be of concern and that specifications should include maximum levels for those constituents as well.

During the manufacturing process, a problematic compound is formed: 4-MEI, evaluated by the IARC as \"potentially carcinogenic to humans.\" Residue can be found in caramel at the conclusion of the production process. \10\10Moreover, sulfites are used in the production of this additive. These compounds may trigger allergies or intolerance reactions.

Annatto is a yellow-orange food coloring derived from the seeds of the achiote tree, a tropical shrub native to Central America. Although it is natural compound, it can be denatured at many stages of processing.\10\10In 2016, the EFSA (European Food Safety Authority) concluded that E160b is safe, despite an observed exceedance of the ADI (acceptable daily intake) of E160b(ii) in a small part of the population.\10\10This same EFSA report further stated that studies showed allergic reactions to certain forms of the additive. However, the panel of experts considered these reactions to be due to residual seed proteins specific to the forms used. For this reason, regulatory specifications were introduced requiring manufacturers to ensure the removal of residual proteins in the final additive product.

Calcium carbonate is a white colorant extracted from limestone. It can also be used as an emulsifier, anti-caking agent, acidity regulator, or stabilizer.\10\10The problem with calcium carbonate is that it can be present in the form of nanoparticles, tiny molecules that can pass through physiological barriers - like the skin -, penetrate into living cells, and accumulate in the body. In 2020, Anses (The French Agency for Food, Environmental and Occupational Health & Safety) included E170 among the list of additives whose presence of nanoparticles was \"proven\". The long-term effects of these nanoparticles are still unknown today. \10\10In its opinion delivered in 2011, the EFSA (European Food Safety Authority) concluded that trace levels of contamination by nanoparticles within calcium carbonate were not of toxicological concern.\10\10 It should however be pointed out that the presence of nanoparticles in E170 was not taken into consideration in the EFSA reevaluation because their specific properties were poorly documented and not well understood at the time.\10

Calcium carbonate is an additive extracted from limestone. The problem with calcium carbonate is that it can be present in the form of nanoparticles, tiny molecules that can penetrate into living cells and accumulate in the body, and whose long-term effects are still unknown.

Titanium dioxide is a mineral consisting of oxygen and titanium. It is used in food products for its color (white pigment) and as an opacifier.\10\10Some titanium dioxide particles found in E171 are smaller than 100 nanometers and are thus considered nanoparticles. The risk associated with titanium dioxide is due in large part to the presence of these nanoparticles.\10\10Since 2013, European regulations have required manufacturers to add a \"nanomaterials\" label if over 50% of total particles are smaller than 100 nanometers. This means that the packaging for a food product containing E171 with 49% of particles being smaller than 100 nm will not carry the \"nanomaterials\" label. According to a 2016 literature review by the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA), the proportion of nanoparticles in titanium dioxide may vary between 0% and 39% in a number of food products currently sold in Europe.\10\10Titanium dioxide was categorized as potentially carcinogenic in humans by the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) in 2006 regarding respiratory/pulmonary exposure. In 2017, the European Agency for Chemical Products (ECHA) categorized titanium dioxide as suspected of causing cancer in humans via inhalation.\10\10A 2017 study conducted on rats by France\'s National Institute for Agricultural Research (INRA) demonstrated that E171 has an adverse impact on the intestinal barrier and suggested an effect on cancer development. \10\10Following that study, the French Agency for Food, Environmental and Occupational Health & Safety (ANSES) also conducted an evaluation of E171. ANSES notes that the study in question reveals effects that had not been identified previously, in particular regarding E171\'s potential effects on cancer development. However, it concludes that these results do not, at this stage, justify a reconsideration of the E171 evaluation made by the EFSA in 2016, which found that current E171 exposure is insufficient to result in risks to health. The EFSA specifically noted an absence of data on E171 and called for reproductive toxicity and genotoxicity studies. ANSES also emphasized the need for additional studies.\10\10Given the potential risks associated with E171, the European Union has decided to ban titanium dioxide as a food additive from 2022, after its safety was questioned by EFSA, which considered that it could no longer considered « safe ».

Titanium dioxide, used primarily as a white pigment, is believed to increase the risk of cancer.\10\10Given the potential risks associated with E171, the European Union has decided to ban titanium dioxide as a food additive from 2022, after its safety was questioned by EFSA, which considered that it could no longer considered « safe ».

Sorbic acid is generally used as a preservative.\10\10Studies have shown that sorbic acid may react, under certain conditions (in vitro, in a laboratory), with nitrites and ascorbic acid to form mutagenic compounds, which are capable of causing changes in the structure of genetic material.\10\10However, the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) dismissed such a risk after its 2015 re-evaluation. It specified that these compounds cannot be formed in significant quantity within food products. \10\10In its 2019 opinion, the EFSA did, however, request further research on the appearance of these potentially concerning compounds. In particular, it asked the industry for information about the stability of this additive during food processing and storage periods. \10\10However, the industry has not provided further information on the topic to the EFSA since 2015.

It is generally used as a preservative.\10\10Studies have shown that sorbic acid may react, under certain conditions (in vitro, in a laboratory), with nitrites and ascorbic acid to form mutagenic compounds, which are capable of causing changes in the structure of genetic material.\10\10However, the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) dismissed such a risk after its 2015 re-evaluation. It specified that these compounds cannot be formed in significant quantity within food products. \10\10In its 2019 opinion, the EFSA did, however, request further research on the appearance of these potentially concerning compounds. In particular, it asked the industry for information about the stability of this additive during food processing and storage periods. \10\10However, the industry has not provided further information on the topic to the EFSA since 2015.

Benzoic acid is a by-product of benzene. It is a preservative found mainly in soft drinks and sauces.\10\10In its 2016 re-evaluation, the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) indicates that this additive may increase hypersensitivity and/or cause skin reactions. The EFSA noted that various cases of intolerance reactions to benzoic acid had been reported in the literature: severe allergic reactions, skin reactions (urticaria, pruritus, etc.), gastrointestinal disorders, bronchial hyperreactivity or asthma attacks, and effects on the central nervous system. \10\10The EFSA indicates that individuals sensitive to benzoic acid may present reactions at doses below the ADI (Acceptable Daily Intake). Moreover, there is a risk that toddlers and children will exceed the ADI if they regularly consume items such as flavored drinks.\10\10This preservative is also believed to promote hyperactivity and attention deficit disorders in children in combination with certain other additives. However, the EFSA dismissed this risk in its 2016 re-evaluation. The results of the most incriminating study (McCann et al., 2007) nonetheless show a real impact on certain populations of individuals with sensitivities to food additives in general or to food dyes specifically.\10\10Finally, in its most recent re-evaluation, the EFSA recommends that maximum limits for the impurities of toxic elements (lead, mercury, and arsenic) in benzoic acid and its salts (E210-E213) be revised in order to ensure that the additives are not a significant source of exposure to these toxic elements.

Benzoic acid may increase hypersensitivity and/or cause intolerance reactions: severe allergic reactions, urticaria, gastrointestinal disorders, skin reactions, bronchial hyperreactivity or asthma attacks, and effects on the central nervous system. \10\10This preservative is also believed to promote hyperactivity and attention deficit disorders in children.

This additive is a sulfite, a sulfur-based compound. Sulfites are used as preservatives (they prevent the development of bacteria and mold) and as antioxidants (they keep products from oxidizing and losing their color). They are often found in wine and in many industrial products (dried fruit, mustard, etc.). Their use is subject to maximum dosage restrictions.\10\10Sulfites may cause severe intolerance reactions (blotchy skin, dermatitis, urticaria, asthma, conjunctivitis, migraine, etc.) in sensitive or asthmatic individuals. According to the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA), 3-10% of people with asthma may have a sulfite intolerance. \10\10Most people with a sensitivity to sulfites develop food intolerance reactions at doses of 20-50 mg per kilogram or liter of sulfites in the food product. As a result, European law requires that sulfites be declared on food labels if their concentration is equal to or greater than 10 mg/kg or 10 mg/L.\10\10In 2011, a study by the French Agency for Food, Environmental and Occupational Health & Safety (ANSES) found that 2.9% of French adults exceeded the ADI (Acceptable Daily Intake), corresponding to specific groups (heavy consumers of wine, for example). Those data from 2011 have not been updated by ANSES since.\10\10In a new opinion issued in 2016, the EFSA found that the current safety level ensured sufficient consumer protection. However, the EFSA also acknowledged that the ADI for sulfites may be exceeded by all age groups and indicated that this is a temporary ADI. The EFSA therefore recommended that the ADI be re-evaluated by 2021, following new studies that will take at least 5 years to conduct. The EFSA also recommends that the exact quantity of sulfites be shown on food packaging, in addition to the \"contains sulfites\" label.

This additive is a sulfite, a sulfur-based compound. \10\10Sulfites may cause severe intolerance reactions (blotchy skin, dermatitis, urticaria, asthma, conjunctivitis, migraine, etc.) in sensitive individuals.

Their use is subject to maximum dosage restrictions.\10\10Sulfites may cause severe intolerance reactions (blotchy skin, dermatitis, urticaria, asthma, conjunctivitis, migraine, etc.) in sensitive or asthmatic individuals. According to the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA), 3-10% of people with asthma may have a sulfite intolerance. \10\10Most people with a sensitivity to sulfites develop food intolerance reactions at doses of 20-50 mg per kilogram or liter of sulfites in the food product. As a result, European law requires that sulfites be declared on food labels if their concentration is equal to or greater than 10 mg/kg or 10 mg/L.\10\10In 2011, a study by the French Agency for Food, Environmental and Occupational Health & Safety (ANSES) found that 2.9% of French adults exceeded the ADI (Acceptable Daily Intake), corresponding to specific groups (heavy consumers of wine, for example). Those data from 2011 have not been updated by ANSES since.\10\10In a new opinion issued in 2016, the EFSA found that the current safety level ensured sufficient consumer protection. However, the EFSA also acknowledged that the ADI for sulfites may be exceeded by all age groups and indicated that this is a temporary ADI. The EFSA therefore recommended that the ADI be re-evaluated by 2021, following new studies that will take at least 5 years to conduct. The EFSA also recommends that the exact quantity of sulfites be shown on food packaging, in addition to the \"contains sulfites\" label.

This additive is commonly used as a preservative and primarily as a mold inhibitor: it is a natural fungicide produced by a bacteria called Streptomyces natalensis. Natamycin is also used in medicine as an antibiotic.\10 \10This additive is authorized only for the surface treatment (rind) of certain cheeses and the casings of certain deli meats (sausages and dry sausages).\10 \10Very high doses and regular intake may cause gastrointestinal problems (nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, bloating). These side effects have been reported in several clinical studies taken into account by EFSA.\10 \10In 2009, EFSA (European Food Safety Authority) concluded that natamycin does not pose a safety risk if it is only used for the surface treatment of the rind of semi-hard and semi-soft cheese and on the casings of certain sausages.\10 \10However, other toxicological studies were published after the scientific opinion delivered by EFSA in 2009. At very high doses, E235 may also trigger a cytotoxic response in certain immune cells, which would inhibit or prevent the proper functioning of these cells. \10 \10Another study also showed that E234 may alter the activity of certain liver enzymes which are crucial to the efficient metabolism of molecules in drugs.\10\10To date, EFSA has not assigned an ADI (acceptable daily intake) for this additive, which would set the maximum amount that can be ingested daily with no appreciable health risk. However, the JECFA (The Joint FAO/WHO Expert Committee on Food Additives) assigned an ADI of 0.3 mg/kg body weight/day.

This additive is authorized only for the surface treatment (rind) of certain cheeses and the casings of certain sausage products.\10 \10Very high doses and regular intake may cause gastrointestinal problems (nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, bloating).\10 \10Moreover, at extremely high doses, E235 may also trigger a cytotoxic response in certain immune cells.

Nitrites are preservatives often used by the food industry, particularly in cooked meats. This additive is added to meat in order to preserve its color and enhance its flavor.\10\10When combined with certain food, nitrite derivatives can contribute to the formation of nitroso compounds, some of which are genotoxic (damaging to DNA).\10\10Although the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) acknowledged in its 2017 opinion that nitrites can contribute to the formation of dangerous compounds, it found that authorized levels of nitrites and nitrates (which are evaluated jointly) provide sufficient protection. \10\10However, it is possible that some consumers\' exposure may exceed the ADI (Admissible Daily Intake). According to EFSA, children with a diet high in foods containing nitrate and nitrite additives slightly exceed ADI. Furthermore, if all dietary sources of nitrites and nitrates are taken into account (as they are found not only in additives, but also in water and in vegetable contaminants, for example), the ADI safety level may be exceeded in any age group. \10\10The EFSA requests additional studies on the conversion of nitrate into nitrite in saliva, the resulting production of methemoglobin, and the consequences on nitrosamine formation in food products containing nitrite additives. Additional human epidemiological studies would also be worthwhile, as would data about nitrate/nitrite exposure from non-additive food sources. This would help to provide a more comprehensive view of exposure, refining future evaluations.\10\10At the request of the French Federation of Industrial Charcutiers, Caterers and Meat Processors (FICT), the following is stated:\10\10The primary reason for its use is the fight against botulism and salmonella. ANSES (French Agency for Food, Environmental and Occupational Health & Safety) Recommendations of December 2019 to charcutiers (...) - Cured meat products: nitrite salt (maximum of 150 mg of nitrites /kg of product) is the most effective inhibitor of Clostridium botulinum.\10\10Also, EFSA experts have concluded that existing safety levels for nitrites and nitrates added to meat and other foods provide adequate protection for consumers.\10\10The ESFA (European Food Safety Authority) states that: The panel of experts concluded that the acceptable daily intake (ADI) set by the SCF (Scientific Committee for Food) in 1997 was sufficiently protective of public health. (...) the formation of nitrosamines in the body from nitrites added at approved levels to meat products is of low concern for human health.
When combined with certain food, nitrite derivatives can contribute to the formation of nitroso compounds, some of which are dangerous to health.

Nitrates are preservatives often used by the food industry, particularly in cooked meats. This additive is added to meat in order to preserve its color and enhance its flavor. It is also used to prevent late blowing defect during fermentation in certain cheeses.\10\10Nitrate is naturally present in some vegetables, with the highest concentrations being found in leafy vegetables, such as spinach and lettuce. Nitrates are also found in high concentration in some waters; this is connected with their use in intensive farming practices, livestock farming, and wastewater discharge.\10\10A large portion of ingested nitrates are eliminated through urine. However, nitrate remaining in the body is, in part, converted into nitrite by bacteria in the mouth. \10\10The concern is that, when combined with certain food, nitrite derivatives can contribute to the formation of nitroso compounds, some of which are genotoxic (damaging to DNA).\10\10Although the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) acknowledged in its 2017 opinion that nitrites can contribute to the formation of dangerous compounds, it found that authorized levels of nitrites and nitrates (which are evaluated jointly) provide sufficient protection. \10\10However, it is possible that some consumers\' exposure may exceed the ADI (Admissible Daily Intake). According to EFSA, children with a diet high in foods containing nitrate and nitrite additives slightly exceed ADI. Furthermore, if all dietary sources of nitrites and nitrates are taken into account (as they are found not only in additives, but also in water and in vegetable contaminants, for example), the ADI safety level may be exceeded in any age group. \10\10The EFSA requests additional studies on the conversion of nitrate into nitrite in saliva, the resulting production of methemoglobin, and the consequences on nitrosamine formation in food products containing nitrite additives. Additional human epidemiological studies would also be worthwhile, as would data about nitrate/nitrite exposure from non-additive food sources. This would help to provide a more comprehensive view of exposure, refining future evaluations.\10\10At the request of the French Federation of Industrial Charcutiers, Caterers and Meat Processors (FICT) and pursuant to a court decision appealed by Yuka, the following is stated:\10\10The primary reason for its use is the fight against botulism and salmonella. (...) the formation of nitrosamines in the body from nitrites added at approved levels to meat products is of low concern for human health.

Propionic acid and its salts are used as preservatives.\10\10The European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) concluded that the use of propionic acid and its salts at the maximum permitted levels does not pose a safety concern. \10\10However, a recent clinical study has shown that propionic acid may impact certain metabolic parameters (glucagon levels in particular).

This additive is used as a preservative and has been approved as a safe ingredient by EFSA. However, a recent clinical study has shown that propionic acid may impact certain metabolic parameters (glucagon levels in particular).

Ascorbic acid, Ascorbic acid added as a dough conditioner
Fatty acid esters of ascorbic acid

This petroleum-derived additive serves as an antioxidant in numerous processed food products. \10\10It is believed to be mutagenic, which means that it is capable of altering the structure of genetic material (studies on this subject are contradictory). Certain studies on rats also show a potential carcinogenic effect on the stomach and thyroid gland.\10\10However, in its reevaluation of 2004, EFSA (European Food Safety Authority) concluded that this additive was not carcinogenic and that genotoxicity studies were not necessary. On the other hand, EFSA deemed that there was a risk of exceeding the ADI (acceptable daily dose) for toddlers and children, based on a new exposure calculation performed in 2016.\10\10According to a more recent 2019 American study conducted on mice, this additive may also weaken our immune system and make us more vulnerable to the flu virus.

This additive is believed to be mutagenic, which means that it is capable of altering the structure of genetic material (studies on this subject are contradictory). \10\10Certain studies on rats also show a potential carcinogenic effect on the stomach and thyroid gland.\10\10Finally, according to an American study in 2019, this additive may also weaken our immune system.

BHA is an antioxidant used to keep fats from becoming rancid and to ensure foods retain their original flavor and color. Since 1987, BHA has been classified by the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) as \"possibly carcinogenic to humans\" (Group 2B). \10\10BHA is believed to be an endocrine disruptor and to cause allergic reactions. \10\10In a re-evaluation from 2011, the EFSA (European Food Safety Authority) found the additive to be harmless in permitted doses. However, this assessment did not address the risks of endocrine disruption. To this day, the data on BHA remains insufficient and further studies are required.\10\10In light of these uncertainties, BHA is currently being evaluated by the ECHA (European Chemicals Agency) as part of the REACH regulation on endocrine disruptors. As of March 24, 2020, the evaluation was still ongoing.

BHA is an antioxidant used to keep fats from becoming rancid and to ensure foods retain their original flavor and color. It has been classified by the IARC as \"possibly carcinogenic to humans\" (Group 2B) since 1987.\10\10BHA is also believed to be an endocrine disruptor and to cause allergic reactions.

Butylhydroxytoluene (BHT) is an antioxidant used to keep fats from becoming rancid and to ensure foods retain their original flavor and color. \10\10Several studies have shown BHT to be an endocrine disruptor. In particular, the additive is believed to affect the thyroid and the sex hormones. Many studies also emphasize the ability of BHT to cross the placental barrier and cause growth retardation and behavioral disorders in children.\10\10However, the ANSES (French National Agency for Food, Environmental, and Occupational Health Safety) concluded in a report from 2015 that BHT was not an endocrine disruptor, largely due to a lack of data. \10\10In light of these uncertainties, the ANSES submitted BHT to the Community Rolling Action Plan (CoRAP) in 2016 for evaluation by the ECHA (European Chemicals Agency) as part of the REACH regulation on endocrine disruptors. As of March 24, 2020, this evaluation was still ongoing.\10\10Finally, several studies reviewed by the EFSA (European Food Safety Authority) in 2012 suggest that BHT may cause allergic reactions, but these studies were ultimately found to be inconclusive.

Butylhydroxytoluene (BHT) is an antioxidant that has been shown by many studies to be an endocrine disruptor. In particular, it is believed to affect the thyroid and the sex hormones.\10\10BHT is currently being evaluated by the ECHA as part of the REACH regulation on endocrine disruptors.

Phosphates are widely used by the food industry because of their various functions as leavening agents, stabilizers, acidity regulators, and humectants. \10\10Phosphates contain phosphorus, a chemical element that is essential to the body. Notably, phosphorus is involved in most biochemical reactions in the body, as well as in bone mineral density; this is why there is a recommended dietary allowance (RDA) for phosphorus. Phosphorus also appears naturally in animal- and vegetable-based products.\10\10However, actual intake now widely exceeds the RDA for phosphorus, due to the presence of phosphate additives in foods and high consumption of meats and dairy products. According to the French Agency for Food, Environmental and Occupational Health & Safety (ANSES), as of 2015, our phosphorus intake is now two or three times greater than needed.\10\10An excess of phosphorus can have troublesome consequences. Indeed, it could increase the risk of cardiovascular disease by causing a calcification of the blood vessels; high consumption of phosphorus has been linked to higher rates of death from cardiovascular disease. An excess of phosphorus could also disrupt calcium metabolism and bone mineralization. Finally, such an excess is harmful to the kidneys, which are involved in the elimination of phosphorus. As a result, people with kidney failure must be particularly careful. \10\10In 2019, the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) re-evaluated the safety of using phosphates as additives. For the first time, it established an Admissible Daily Intake (ADI), which was set at 40 mg per kg of body weight per day. This ADI is evaluated by accounting for phosphorus intake from all sources (additives and phosphorus naturally present in animal and plant proteins).\10\10However, the EFSA also notes that intake of phosphates from food may exceed that dose among newborns and children with average phosphate intake and among teenagers with higher than average phosphate intake. Moreover, this ADI does not apply to people with kidney failure, who are a more vulnerable population. For the time being, EFSA finds evidence of a risk of cardiovascular disease linked to excessive phosphorus intake from food to be insufficient and indicates that more studies are required.\10\10Finally, the EFSA recommends introducing new maximum authorized levels to reduce the phosphate content of food additives, as people who consume them regularly could run a risk of kidney disease (phosphates are currently authorized, without limitation, for use in food additives).

Phosphates contain phosphorus, a chemical element that is essential to the body. However, according to ANSES, our phosphorus intake is now two or three times greater than needed.\10\10Excess phosphorus may increase the risk of cardiovascular diseases, disrupt calcium metabolism and bone mineralization, and negatively affect the kidneys.

Phosphates are widely used by the food industry because of their various functions as leavening agents, stabilizers, acidity regulators, and humectants. \10\10Phosphates contain phosphorus, a chemical element that is essential to the body. Notably, phosphorus is involved in most biochemical reactions in the body, as well as in bone mineral density; this is why there is a recommended dietary allowance (RDA) for phosphorus. Phosphorus also appears naturally in animal- and vegetable-based products.\10\10However, actual intake now widely exceeds the RDA for phosphorus, due to the presence of phosphate additives in foods and high consumption of meats and dairy products. According to the French Agency for Food, Environmental and Occupational Health & Safety (ANSES), as of 2015, our phosphorus intake is now two or three times greater than needed.\10\10An excess of phosphorus can have troublesome consequences. Indeed, it could increase the risk of cardiovascular disease by causing a calcification of the blood vessels; high consumption of phosphorus has been linked to higher rates of death from cardiovascular disease. An excess of phosphorus could also disrupt calcium metabolism and bone mineralization. Finally, such an excess is harmful to the kidneys, which are involved in the elimination of phosphorus. As a result, people with kidney failure must be particularly careful. \10\10In 2019, the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) re-evaluated the safety of using phosphates as additives. For the first time, it established an Admissible Daily Intake (ADI), which was set at 40 mg per kg of body weight per day. This ADI is evaluated by accounting for phosphorus intake from all sources (additives and phosphorus naturally present in animal and plant proteins).\10\10However, the EFSA also notes that intake of phosphates from food may exceed that dose among newborns and children with average phosphate intake and among teenagers with higher than average phosphate intake. Moreover, this ADI does not apply to people with kidney failure, who are a more vulnerable population. For the time being, EFSA finds evidence of a risk of cardiovascular disease linked to excessive phosphorus intake from food to be insufficient and indicates that more studies are required.\10\10Finally, the EFSA recommends introducing new maximum authorized levels to reduce the phosphate content of food additives, as people who consume them regularly could run a risk of kidney disease (phosphates are currently authorized, without limitation, for use in food additives).

For the first time, it established an Admissible Daily Intake (ADI), which was set at 40 mg per kg of body weight per day. This ADI is evaluated by accounting for phosphorus intake from all sources (additives and phosphorus naturally present in animal and plant proteins).\10\10However, the EFSA also notes that intake of phosphates from food may exceed that dose among newborns and children with average phosphate intake and among teenagers with higher than average phosphate intake. Moreover, this ADI does not apply to people with kidney failure, who are a more vulnerable population. For the time being, EFSA finds evidence of a risk of cardiovascular disease linked to excessive phosphorus intake from food to be insufficient and indicates that more studies are required.\10\10Finally, the EFSA recommends introducing new maximum authorized levels to reduce the phosphate content of food additives, as people who consume them regularly could run a risk of kidney disease (phosphates are currently authorized, without limitation, for use in food additives).

EDTA is an antioxidant that protects food from deterioration and also preserves the flavor and color of food.\10\10In high doses, it can cause various adverse reactions: poor mineral absorption leading to mineral deficiencies, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal or muscle cramps, blood clotting disorders, and blood in the urine.

This additive is believed to be mutagenic, which means that it is capable of altering the structure of genetic material (studies on this subject are contradictory). \10\10Certain studies on rats also show a potential carcinogenic effect on the stomach and thyroid gland.\10\10Finally, according to an American study in 2019, this additive may also weaken our immune system.

Carrageenans are red seaweed extracts used as additives for their thickening and gelling properties.\10\10When cooked at high temperatures or processed in highly acidic environments, a portion of the carrageenans may create \"degraded carrageenans.\" These degraded carrageenans are classified as \"possibly carcinogenic to humans\" (Group 2B) by the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC). \10\10These degraded carrageenans can more easily cross the intestinal barrier. Some pig studies have demonstrated a link between the ingestion of degraded carrageenans and the presence of inflammation or even ulcers in the colon. However, more recent studies performed on rats showed no effect on the development of colon cancer. Indeed, studies do not always specify what types of carrageenans are used, as a chemical distinction is not made between native and degraded carrageenans. As a result, chemical characterization is a prerequisite for a proper interpretation of experiment results. \10\10In its 2018 evaluation, the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) acknowledges studies indicating that these degraded carrageenans have negative impacts on human health, but it specifies that this type of carrageenan as such is not authorized for use in the European Union as an additive.\10\10Regarding native carrageenans, in 2018 the EFSA deemed that this additive does not pose any cancer risk to humans in the maximum authorized doses. However, the EFSA finds that some populations are exposed to native carrageenans in quantities 10 times the current ADI (Acceptable Daily Intake), which poses a health risk. The EFSA thus considers the established ADI to be temporary and points to the need for further studies on this additive within 5 years of the re-evaluation date; the next opinion is therefore planned for release in 2023.

Sorbitol is considered a bulk sweetener, which are different from so-called intense sweeteners. Unlike intense sweeteners, bulk sweeteners have less sweetening power than sugar (sucrose). Sorbitol is naturally present in certain fruits and has half the sweetening power of sugar (sucrose). In the industry, it is derived from starch (most often corn starch). It can also be used for its texture properties, to thicken or stabilize products. Moreover, sorbitol is found naturally in apples, pears, peaches, and apricots.\10\10In the event of heavy consumption, sorbitol may cause digestive issues (diarrhea, bloating, flatulence). As a result, foodstuffs containing more than 10% sorbitol must bear the statement, \"Excess consumption may have a laxative effect.\" Moreover, sorbitol is prohibited for use in beverages and baby products.\10\10Generally speaking, sweeteners may also disrupt the intestinal flora and promote metabolic disorders, particularly the risk of developing type 2 diabetes. Although sorbitol and other bulk sweeteners lead to a better glycemic response than sugar, few studies have been conducted on their impact on the intestinal flora, weight gain, or the risk of type 2 diabetes.\10\10The European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) has planned to re-evaluate bulk and intense sweeteners by December 2020. In connection with this, it launched appeals for toxicological (2017) and compositional data (2018) from the industry. Sorbitol will be re-evaluated in light of these new data.

Sorbitol is an additive used to provide sweetness or texture in order to thicken or stabilize products. It is prohibited for use in beverages and baby products.\10\10In the event of heavy consumption, sorbitol may cause digestive issues (diarrhea, bloating, flatulence).

Glycerol (or glycerin) is an additive that may be natural or synthetic. It is generally used as a humectant: It preserves a product\'s humidity and prevents drying. \10\10In its 2017 opinion, the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) noted that some residual contaminants from the industrial synthesis of glycerol, including arsenic and acrolein, may be found in food. \10\10As a result, in 2018, the EFSA called for technological data on the industrial glycerol manufacturing process in order to limit the presence of contaminants. \10\10Moreover, glycerol is prohibited for use in baby products.

Polysorbates (E432 - E436) are additives made from sorbitol (E420). They are used as emulsifiers that permit the mixture of two immiscible substances, like oil and water, and prevent the formation of deposits. They are commonly found in coconut milk and coconut cream.\10\10Emulsifiers are believed to disrupt intestinal flora and increase the risk of autoimmune disorders, allergies, and inflammatory diseases. \10\10Inflammation resulting from the alteration of the gut microbiota by emulsifiers may even promote the development of colon cancer, according to a recent study (Viennois, 2017).\10\10In its 2015 reevaluation of these additives, EFSA (European Food Safety Authority) reported that, at the time, the data was insufficient to measure the actual exposure to these additives, and that there were potential risks for exceeding the ADI (acceptable daily intake) in certain population groups (primarily young children). However, EFSA concluded that there were no concerns regarding genotoxicity, carcinogenicity, or reproductive toxicity. EFSA recognized the existence of incriminating data on the gastrointestinal microbiota but did not formally take them into account in its risk evaluation.

Brominated vegetable oil is obtained when bromine, a naturally-occurring chemical element, is added to vegetable oil (often soybean) to increase the density of the oil and make it easier to mix with essential oils (lemon, in particular) used in soft drinks. During the process, brominated fatty acids form. This additive is banned in many countries (including the countries of Europe) but approved for use in the United States and Canada, where it is found in certain soft drinks.\10\10Bromine compounds have been suspected to be carcinogenic, neurotoxic, and genotoxic. Several cases of bromine poisoning by way of soft drinks have been reported in the United States.\10 \10Brominated vegetable oils were designated as \"GRAS\" (Generally Recognized As Safe) in the United States as early as 1958, but this status was revoked in the 1970s. Pending the results of ongoing toxicological tests, this additive remains approved for use in the United States and Canada in quantities of no more than 15 ppm of a finished product. In 1970, the WHO evaluated this additive but lacked the toxicological data required to reach a conclusion and was unable to establish an acceptable daily intake (ADI).

Phosphates are widely used by the food industry because of their various functions as leavening agents, stabilizers, acidity regulators, and humectants. \10\10Phosphates contain phosphorus, a chemical element that is essential to the body. Notably, phosphorus is involved in most biochemical reactions in the body, as well as in bone mineral density; this is why there is a recommended dietary allowance (RDA) for phosphorus. Phosphorus also appears naturally in animal- and vegetable-based products.\10\10However, actual intake now widely exceeds the RDA for phosphorus, due to the presence of phosphate additives in foods and high consumption of meats and dairy products. According to the French Agency for Food, Environmental and Occupational Health & Safety (ANSES), as of 2015, our phosphorus intake is now two or three times greater than needed.\10\10An excess of phosphorus can have troublesome consequences. Indeed, it could increase the risk of cardiovascular disease by causing a calcification of the blood vessels; high consumption of phosphorus has been linked to higher rates of death from cardiovascular disease. According to the French Agency for Food, Environmental and Occupational Health & Safety (ANSES), as of 2015, our phosphorus intake is now two or three times greater than needed.\10\10An excess of phosphorus can have troublesome consequences. Indeed, it could increase the risk of cardiovascular disease by causing a calcification of the blood vessels; high consumption of phosphorus has been linked to higher rates of death from cardiovascular disease. An excess of phosphorus could also disrupt calcium metabolism and bone mineralization. Finally, such an excess is harmful to the kidneys, which are involved in the elimination of phosphorus. As a result, people with kidney failure must be particularly careful. \10\10In 2019, the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) re-evaluated the safety of using phosphates as additives. For the first time, it established an Admissible Daily Intake (ADI), which was set at 40 mg per kg of body weight per day. This ADI is evaluated by accounting for phosphorus intake from all sources (additives and phosphorus naturally present in animal and plant proteins).\10\10However, the EFSA also notes that intake of phosphates from food may exceed that dose among newborns and children with average phosphate intake and among teenagers with higher than average phosphate intake. Moreover, this ADI does not apply to people with kidney failure, who are a more vulnerable population. For the time being, EFSA finds evidence of a risk of cardiovascular disease linked to excessive phosphorus intake from food to be insufficient and indicates that more studies are required.\10\10Finally, the EFSA recommends introducing new maximum authorized levels to reduce the phosphate content of food additives, as people who consume them regularly could run a risk of kidney disease (phosphates are currently authorized, without limitation, for use in food additives).

Sodium carboxymethylcellulose (or cellulose gum) is an additive that can have multiple uses, including as an emulsifier, thickener, setting agent, glazing agent, and stabilizer. However, it is classified as an emulsifier. Emulsifiers make it possible to create an emulsion of two liquids that do not mix (oil and water, for example).\10\10In its 2018 re-evaluation, the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) deemed that this additive provided no cause for concern and that the available data did not point to any risk of genotoxicity, carcinogenicity, or reproductive toxicity. However, that opinion does not take into account some recent, incriminating studies regarding emulsifiers.\10\10Moreover, the EFSA did not study digestive upset or the risks of increased intestinal permeability or changes to intestinal flora, concerns raised by recent animal studies.\10\10Indeed, some studies suggest that emulsifiers modify intestinal permeability, causing intestinal barrier dysfunction. They may thus increase the risk of auto-immune disorders (such as Crohn\'s disease) and allergies.\10\10Other studies suggest that emulsifiers may disrupt the intestinal flora and promote inflammation, increasing the risk of inflammatory diseases and metabolic syndrome. Inflammation resulting from modification of the flora by emulsifiers may even promote the development of colon cancer, according to a recent study (Viennois, 2017).\10\10Moreover, experts have called for a revision of specifications pertaining to this additive (heavy metal and solvent residue levels, etc.). Indeed, the Panel on Food Additives and Nutrient Sources Added to Food (ANS) noted gaps in the conclusions and recommendations in opinions published in 2018 (regarding heavy metal levels, for example). The European Commission has asked EFSA to remedy this lack of data. A call for data was therefore made, in order to submit documented information to fill the identified gaps in the data.

This additive is commonly used as a texturizing agent in baked goods (sandwich bread, milk bread, brioches, rusks, etc.). In Europe, it is not approved for use in organic food products.\10\10The acceptable daily intake (ADI) is often exceeded, especially in children.\10\10Moreover, a recent in vitro study (Elmén, 2020) showed that sodium lactylates have the capacity to alter gut microbiota composition.

Calcium sulfate is the calcium salt of sulfuric acid (E513). It is commonly used as an acidity regulator and to improve the stability of food products.\10\10At high doses, sulfates derived from calcium sulfate may cause digestive disorders like nausea, vomiting, or intestinal obstruction. \10\10However, in its 2019 evaluation, EFSA (European Food Safety Authority) concluded that exposure to calcium sulfate did not raise a safety concern at the reported uses and use levels. EFSA acknowledged the risk of a laxative effect in cases of high exposure: the threshold dose that would induce such an effect in humans was therefore set at 300 mg/kg body weight per day. However, according to the calculations of the EFSA, the amount of exposure for European consumers is well below this dose.
Calcium sulfate is commonly used as an acidity regulator.\10\10At high doses, sulfates derived from calcium sulfate may cause digestive disorders like nausea, vomiting, or intestinal obstruction.

This additive is used in baking powder. It is only permitted for use in very specific sponge-cake products.\10\10It is composed of a mixture of aluminum and phosphoric acid. Therefore, it contributes to the total dietary intake of aluminum, which is too high for a large part of the population, according to the 2008 scientific opinion of the EFSA (European Food Safety Authority). \10\10Once it is in our bodies, most aluminum is rapidly eliminated via the feces. However, a small portion can then be taken up in the bloodstream and transported into the various tissues of the body, particularly the bones (possibility of accumulation), liver, lungs, kidneys, and brain.\10\10Therefore, it can cause serious health problems:\10- First, it could significantly potentiate oxidative stress. This can induce the amplification and progression of chronic inflammation in many diseases like multiple sclerosis, Crohn\'s disease, asthma, autism, infertility, and epilepsy.\10- Aluminum could also deposit in the brain cells and impair cerebral function. It has therefore been implicated in Alzheimer\'s disease and several other neurological conditions.\10- Aluminum is a known mutagen, that is, an agent capable of inducing changes in the structure of genetic material.\10- It has also been found to adversely affect fetal development.\10\10This additive also contains phosphorus, a chemical element essential for many biological processes. Notably, phosphorus is involved in most biochemical reactions in the body, as well as in bone mineral density; this is why there is a recommended dietary allowance (RDA) for phosphorus. Phosphorus is naturally found in animal- and vegetable-based products.\10\10However, the current actual intakes of phosphorus greatly exceed the recommended allowance for this mineral. In fact, according to the scientific opinion of the EFSA (European Food Safety Authority) delivered in 2015, our intake is 2 to 3 times greater than our requirements due to the presence of phosphate additives in our diet and high consumption of meat and dairy products. Therefore, as concluded by the EFSA in 2019, our actual exposure exceeds the proposed ADI (acceptable daily intake) for phosphates expressed in the quantity of phosphorus. In its scientific opinion delivered in 2016, the ARS (Agricultural Research Service) in the United States also concluded that phosphorous intakes are above the recommended amounts.\10\10An excess of phosphorus can lead to serious consequences. It may increase the risk of cardiovascular disease by causing calcification of the blood vessels; in fact, a high phosphorus intake has been linked to increased mortality from cardiovascular disease. Excessive phosphorus intake could also disrupt calcium metabolism and bone mineralization. Finally, a high intake of the mineral is harmful to the kidneys, which are responsible for the elimination of extra phosphorus. As a result, people with kidney disease should pay particular attention to their phosphorus intake.

This additive is composed of a mixture of aluminum and phosphoric acid. It contributes to the total dietary intake of aluminum, which is too high for a large part of the population.\10\10It also contains phosphorous, an element that currently consumed in overly high quantities. Excess intakes of phosphorus may significantly increase the risk of cardiovascular disease and disrupt proper calcium metabolism.

Silicon dioxide is used as an anti-caking agent to prevent ingredients in powdered form from clumping due to moisture.\10\10The problem with this additive is that it can contain nanoparticles, which are tiny molecules (less than 100 nanometers). Because of their composition and their ability to transform when they come in with other substances (blood, saliva, etc.), the effects of nanoparticles on humans can vary and are difficult to evaluate. They can cross the intestinal barrier and reach secondary target organs, like the heart or kidneys, where they can accumulate.\10\10Nanoparticles can induce oxidative stress in certain intestinal cells and alter their composition.\10\10Moreover, another study conducted on mice showed that silicon dioxide nanoparticles may damage kidney tissue and impair liver function.\10\10In its 2019 reevaluation, EFSA (European Food Safety Authority) concluded that a clear characterization of particle size distribution was required. It reported a lack of sufficient data on this additive and also recommended chronic toxicity studies that would take into account the presence of a nanoscale fraction of particles in the additive.

This additive may contain nanoparticles, tiny molecules that may induce oxidative stress in certain intestinal cells and alter their composition.\10\10Silicon dioxide nanoparticles can also damage kidney tissue and impair liver function.

Monosodium glutamate (MSG) is a flavor enhancer used in many products to intensify flavors. MSG provides umami, often called the fifth basic taste.\10\10It is found in many industrial food products, such as potato chips, cookies, soups, preserves, etc. It can also be found in Asian dishes, such as nems, fried rice, and soy sauce. However, it is prohibited in organic products.\10\10Monosodium glutamate has long been blamed for \"Chinese restaurant syndrome.\" That term is now obsolete, having been replaced by the term \"MSG symptom complex,\" which includes the symptoms experienced by some individuals after a meal in a Chinese restaurant, which may be caused by the frequent use of MSG in Chinese cooking. These symptoms include nausea and vomiting, migraine, skin flushing, a burning sensation, hot flashes, etc. Indeed, a number of studies have demonstrated that presence of some of these symptoms in a subset of participants when exposed to a high dose of MSG. The mechanism behind this cluster of symptoms, however, remains unknown.\10\10Moreover, MSG is believed to stimulate appetite, thus increasing the quantity of food ingested. It may therefore promote weight gain and obesity. Several studies (particularly on mice and rats) have thus shown that the use of high doses of monosodium glutamate leads to increased body weight and body fat. Human studies have also shown a positive link between MSG consumption and weight gain. Indeed, glutamate may trigger resistance to leptin, the satiety hormone.\10\10Monosodium glutamate may also contribute to diabetes risk. Indeed, several studies have shown that monosodium glutamate leads to a spike in insulin (the hormone secreted by the pancreas to lower blood sugar). Hyperinsulinemia has been demonstrated in a number of studies. Some studies suggest that monosodium glutamate may contribute to the development of diabetes (types 1 and 2).\10\10Finally, monosodium glutamate is believed to play a role in the development of neurodegenerative disorders such as Alzheimer\'s disease and Parkinson\'s disease, as well as autoimmune disorders such as multiple sclerosis. A high concentration of glutamate is in fact responsible for the destruction of neurons through a process called excitotoxicity. Monosodium glutamate consumption also affects the operation of leptin, which plays a role in cerebral functions such as learning and memory. Through its effect on leptin, then, monosodium glutamate may also play a role in neurodegenerative disorders.\10\10In 2017, the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) re-evaluated the safety of using glutamates as food additives. Until that time, no ADI (Acceptable Daily Intake) had been established. The EFSA calculated an ADI of 30 mg per kg of body weight per day for the six additives in that group. It also found that our dietary exposure to glutamates may exceed that safety limit, leading to adverse effects on humans for certain population groups. The EFSA\'s expert panel therefore recommends a revision of the maximum levels of added glutamates in the food products that contribute most to exposure (fine bakery products, soups and broths, sauces, meat and meat-based products, seasonings and condiments, and dietary supplements).

Consumption of glutamate may cause a variety of symptoms, including nausea, migraine, skin flushing, hot flashes, etc.\10\10Moreover, glutamate may contribute to weight gain, obesity, and diabetes risk.\10\10Finally, glutamate is believed to play a role in the development of neurodegenerative and auto-immune disorders.

This additive is used as a flavor enhancer to intensify the taste of food products. It is often combined with another flavor enhancer, sodium glutamate (E621) to increase its effectiveness. \10 \10Once it is metabolized in the body, this additive is degraded into uric acid. High concentrations of uric acid in the blood can cause gout in predisposed individuals. \10 \10This additive is undergoing reevaluation by EFSA (European Food Safety Authority) to determine its safety for use in human nutrition.

This additive is used as a flavor enhancer to intensify the taste of food products.\10 \10Once it is metabolized in the body, this additive is degraded into uric acid. High concentrations of uric acid in the blood can cause gout in predisposed individuals.

Potassium bromate is often added to flour to help it rise faster and thus cut down on cooking times.\10\10It is banned in many countries (including Canada and European countries) but approved for use in flour in the United States. It can therefore be found in products such as breads and pastries.\10\10Since 1999, potassium bromate has been classified by the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) as \"possibly carcinogenic to humans\" (Group 2B). In an evaluation from 1995, the JECFA (Joint FAO/WHO Expert Committee on Food Additives) advised against its use as an additive in food. \10\10When cooked, potassium bromate decomposes to form harmless potassium bromide. But if potassium bromate is not cooked for long enough or at a high enough temperature, or if too much of the additive is used, then harmful residues can remain.

Azodicarbonamide (ADC) - or azoformamide - is an additive used as a white dye or a leavening agent. It is banned in many countries (including the countries of Europe since 2005) but approved in quantities of up to 45 ppm in flours (parts per million) in the United States and Canada.\10\10It is mainly found in breads (sandwich breads, muffin breads, etc.) and packaged bakery goods such as croissants.\10\10ADC is dangerous because it can degrade and form semicarbazide (SEM). In an evaluation on semicarbazide from 2005, the EFSA (European Food Safety Authority) found little risk to European consumers. However, several studies have shown that at a certain level, the substance becomes carcinogenic. As a result, azodicarbonamide has been banned in Europe.
