Acesulfame potassium is a very powerful artificial sweetener, about 200 times sweeter than sugar (sucrose). It is used in many so-called \"light\" or sugar-free products. \10\10Several potential effects of acesulfame potassium have drawn concern:\10\10• Acesulfame potassium and weight management\10\10In 2015, the French Agency for Food, Environmental and Occupational Health & Safety (ANSES) found a \"lack of nutritional benefit\" for the consumption of intense sweeteners. Its work revealed no effect of intense sweeteners on weight control. ANSES also recommends investigations of possible interactions among build, consumption of intense sweeteners, and weight gain. Moreover, some recent data suggest a link between consumption of sweeteners and weight gain. \10\10• Acesulfame potassium and diabetes\10\10Sweeteners may disrupt the intestinal flora and promote metabolic disorders, particularly glucose intolerance (a frequent step in developing type 2 diabetes). In addition, a study by the French National Institute for Health and Medical Research (INSERM) demonstrates that diet beverages are associated with an increased risk of type 2 diabetes.\10\10• Acesulfame potassium and cancer\10\10In 2005 the National Toxicology Program showed that there was no proof of carcinogenic activity in mice exposed to multiple doses of acesulfame potassium. Meanwhile, ANSES noted in 2015 that epidemiological studies on intense sweeteners demonstrated no effect on cancer in humans. Only one study, from 2012, suggests a link between the consumption of artificially sweetened beverages and the occurrence of non-Hodgkin\'s lymphoma (cancer of the lymphatic system) and myeloma (bone marrow cancer) in humans.\10\10• Acesulfame potassium and premature birth\10\10A study conducted on pregnant women in Denmark reported a link between the consumption of artificially sweetened beverages and a risk of premature delivery. Another study, which followed over 60,000 pregnant women, suggested that consumption of both naturally and artificially sweetened beverages is linked to a heightened risk of spontaneous or induced premature delivery. \10\10\10The European Union\'s Scientific Committee on Food (SCF) re-evaluated the sweetener in 2000 and reaffirmed the absence of carcinogenic and mutagenic potential. However, the approval file was questioned by some researchers due to an absence of studies proving the sweetener\'s harmlessness. The European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) is currently conducting a safety re-evaluation, with a December 2020 deadline for publication of an opinion.\10\10In France, ANSES specified in its 2015 opinion that its work did not demonstrate any benefit to consumption of intense sweeteners on weight control, on blood sugar in diabetic subjects, or on the incidence of type 2 diabetes. It also indicated that its work did not establish any link showing increased risk of diabetes or cancer. However, it noted the need for new studies about the benefits and risks of sweeteners. In light of recent, incriminating studies, and while waiting for the EFSA\'s forthcoming re-evaluation, we recommend limiting the consumption of foods or beverages containing acesulfame potassium.\10

Acesulfame potassium is an intense sweetener. In 2015, the ANSES indicated that intense sweeteners had no effect on weight control.\10\10Moreover, sweeteners may promote metabolic disorders, such as glucose intolerance.\10\10The approval file for this additive has been called into question by some researchers. The EFSA is currently re-evaluating its safety.

Aspartame is an artificial sweetener that is 150 to 200 times as sweet as sugar (sucrose). It is used in many so-called \"light\" or sugar-free products. Aspartame is currently implicated in several health risks:\10\10• Aspartame and weight management\10\10In 2015, the French Agency for Food, Environmental and Occupational Health & Safety (ANSES) found a \"lack of nutritional benefit\" for the consumption of intense sweeteners. Its work revealed no effect, whether positive or negative, of intense sweeteners on weight control. ANSES also recommends investigations of possible interactions among build, consumption of intense sweeteners, and weight gain. Broadly speaking, the issue of nutritional risks linked to consumption of sweeteners remains unclear. Moreover, some recent data suggest a link between consumption of sweeteners and weight gain. \10\10• Aspartame and diabetes\10\10Sweeteners may disrupt the intestinal flora and promote metabolic disorders, particularly glucose intolerance (a frequent step in developing type 2 diabetes). In addition, a study by the French National Institute for Health and Medical Research (INSERM) demonstrates that diet beverages are associated with an increased risk of type 2 diabetes.\10\10• Aspartame and cancer\10\10A mouse study conducted by an Italian research team shows that aspartame consumption increases the incidence of cancer in male mice. That study followed up on two incriminating studies conducted on rats by the same team. Another study, from 2012, suggests a link between the consumption of artificially sweetened beverages and the occurrence of non-Hodgkin\'s lymphoma (cancer of the lymphatic system) and myeloma (bone marrow cancer) in humans.\10\10• Aspartame and premature birth\10\10A study conducted on pregnant women in Denmark reported a link between the consumption of artificially sweetened beverages and a risk of premature delivery. Another study, which followed over 60,000 pregnant women, suggested that consumption of both naturally and artificially sweetened beverages is linked to a heightened risk of spontaneous or induced premature delivery. \10\10• Aspartame and epilepsy \10\10Some studies have suggested that aspartame consumption may cause certain epileptic seizures in children to last longer. \10\10• Aspartame and migraine\10\10Studies show that aspartame consumption may be correlated with migraine triggers or increased frequency of migraines. \10\10\10In its 2015 opinion, the French agency ANSES specified that its work did not demonstrate any benefit to consumption of intense sweeteners on weight control, on blood sugar in diabetic subjects, or on the incidence of type 2 diabetes. It also indicated that its work did not establish any link showing increased risk of diabetes or cancer. However, it noted the need for new studies about the benefits and risks of sweeteners. \10\10Meanwhile, in its 2013 opinion, the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) deemed aspartame safe for consumption at current levels of exposure. According to the EFSA, the current acceptable daily intake (ADI) of 40 mg per kg of body weight per day provides adequate protection for the general public. \10\10However, a study published in July 2019 by two researchers at the University of Sussex in the United Kingdom challenges the EFSA\'s position. Indeed, the authors indicate that the EFSA excluded from its analysis 73 studies showing harmful effects of aspartame (brain damage, liver and lung cancers, neuroendocrine disorders), while most of the studies showing insufficient evidence were in fact included in the analysis. According to these researchers, the majority of the 73 rejected studies were more reliable than those showing no risks. The authors suggest that the EFSA may have been influenced by commercial or institutional conflicts of interest. They therefore call for an independent re-evaluation to be conducted in Europe.\10\10In light of recent, incriminating studies, and while waiting for the EFSA\'s re-evaluation, we recommend limiting the consumption of beverages containing aspartame.

In 2015, ANSES indicated that intense sweeteners such as aspartame had no effect on weight control. Moreover, sweeteners may promote metabolic disorders, such as glucose intolerance. \10\10Aspartame is also suspected of promoting the risk of cancer and of premature birth. It may also trigger migraines.

Sucralose is an intense artificial sweetener that is 500 to 600 times as sweet as sugar (sucrose).\10\10In 2015, the French Agency for Food, Environmental and Occupational Health & Safety (ANSES) found a \"lack of nutritional benefit\" for the consumption of intense sweeteners. Its work revealed no effect, whether positive or negative, of intense sweeteners on weight control. ANSES also recommends investigations of possible interactions among build, consumption of intense sweeteners, and weight gain. Broadly speaking, the issue of nutritional risks linked to consumption of sweeteners remains unclear. Moreover, some recent data suggest a link between consumption of sweeteners and weight gain. \10\10Moreover, several clinical trials specifically dealing with sucralose suggest a detrimental effect of sucralose on humans, in particular with regard to blood sugar, insulin sensitivity, and quantity of food consumed. However, another clinical study did not reveal such impacts, most likely due to a difference in experimental protocols. In any case, these contradictory results highlight the need for a re-evaluation by the competent authorities of the nutritional risks linked to sucralose.\10\10Generally speaking, sweeteners may also disrupt the intestinal flora and promote metabolic disorders, particularly the risk of developing type 2 diabetes. In addition, a study by the French National Institute for Health and Medical Research (INSERM) demonstrates that diet beverages are associated with an increased risk of type 2 diabetes.\10\10Finally, a 2016 study suggested a link between sucralose consumption by mouth in mice and the occurrence of cancer. However, the EFSA received a complaint from the European Commission on the topic and, in its most recent opinion (2017), deemed that sucralose did not have carcinogenic potential.\10\10Specific data about sucralose remain insufficient to date. The EFSA is currently re-evaluating sucralose.

Sucralose is an intense artificial sweetener with significant sweetening power. In 2015, the ANSES indicated that intense sweeteners had no effect on weight control. \10\10Moreover, sweeteners may promote metabolic disorders, such as glucose intolerance.

Steviol glycosides are intense sweeteners made from a South American plant called Stevia rebaudiana. This plant naturally contains a blend of steviol glycosides (primarily stevioside, rebaudioside A, rebaudioside C, and dulcoside A). This combination of glycosides is more than 300 times sweeter than sugar (sucrose) and has no calories. For that reason, this additive is often used as a sugar substitute in so-called \"light\" products.\10\10In 2015, the French Agency for Food, Environmental and Occupational Health & Safety (ANSES) found a \"lack of nutritional benefit\" for the consumption of intense sweeteners, including steviol glycosides. Its work revealed no effect, whether positive or negative, of intense sweeteners on weight control. ANSES also recommends investigations of possible interactions among build, consumption of intense sweeteners, and weight gain. Broadly speaking, the issue of nutritional risks linked to consumption of sweeteners remains unclear. Moreover, some recent data suggest a link between consumption of sweeteners and weight gain. \10\10Generally speaking, sweeteners may also disrupt the intestinal flora and promote metabolic disorders, particularly the risk of developing type 2 diabetes. In addition, a study by the French National Institute for Health and Medical Research (INSERM) demonstrates that diet beverages are associated with an increased risk of type 2 diabetes.\10\10E960 is a relatively new additive (approved for use in the European Union since 2011), and research on its long-term effects is lacking. It has only recently been learned that steviol glycosides can be metabolized by the intestinal flora; only steviol is absorbed by the intestine, processed in the liver, and eliminated through the urine. The effects of steviol glycosides on the intestinal flora and the nutritional risks they may present remain unexplored.

Steviol glycosides are intense sweeteners. In 2015, the ANSES indicated that intense sweeteners had no effect on weight control. \10\10Moreover, sweeteners may promote metabolic disorders, such as glucose intolerance. \10\10E960 is a relatively new additive, and research on its long-term effects is lacking.

Maltitol (E965i) and maltitol syrup (E965ii) are food additives categorized as bulk sweeteners. Unlike intense sweeteners, bulk sweeteners have less sweetening power than sugar (sucrose). Maltitols are approximately 75% as sweet as sugar. Maltitols are also used as humectants, in order to maintain products\' humidity and prevent them from drying out.\10\10In the event of heavy consumption, maltitol may cause digestive issues (diarrhea, bloating, flatulence). As a result, foodstuffs containing more than 10% sorbitol must bear the statement, \"Excess consumption may have a laxative effect.\" Moreover, maltitol is prohibited for use in beverages and baby products.\10\10Generally speaking, sweeteners may also disrupt the intestinal flora and promote metabolic disorders, particularly the risk of developing type 2 diabetes. Although maltitol and other bulk sweeteners lead to a better glycemic response than sugar, few studies have been conducted on their impact on the intestinal flora, weight gain, or the risk of type 2 diabetes.\10\10The European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) has planned to re-evaluate bulk and intense sweeteners by December 2020. In connection with this, it launched appeals for toxicological (2017) and compositional data (2018) from the industry. Maltitol will be re-evaluated in light of these new data.

Maltitol is an additive used as a sweetener or humectant, in order to maintain products\' humidity. It is prohibited for use in beverages and baby products.\10\10In the event of heavy consumption, maltitol may cause digestive issues (diarrhea, bloating, flatulence).

Sustainable palm oil comes from crops that guarantee the preservation of the rainforest. This means that no new forest land will be sacrificed to produce this oil.

Uncertified palm oil is the main cause of deforestation in Malaysia and Indonesia. These regions have a tropical forest that plays a crucial role in regulating the climate by storing large amounts of carbon.
The destruction of the forest also leads to a loss of habitat for many species that are in danger of extinction. This is the case for orangutans, elephants, rhinoceroses and tigers.
The RSPO label, \10co-founded by the WWF, \10guarantees that palm oil is \10cultivated without deforestation, while\10respecting the forest and the species that live in it.

Products for which the list of ingredients is in a language other than English, French, Italian, German or Spanish.
Products sold by weight (cut products, catering products, etc.): these products have a weight-related barcode that is not a unique barcode and does not allow us to identify them.
Products without nutritional value: nutrition facts (calories, sugar, salt, protein, fiber, saturated fat) are essential for calculating the score.

Scoring method is based on three criteria:

The calculation method is based on Nutri-Score, a rating system developed by international research teams that measures the nutritional value of food products. This method looks at the following elements: calories, sugar, salt, saturated fat, protein, fiber, fruits and vegetables.
Yuka supplemented the Nutri-Score method to give it more depth and avoid Nutri-Score\'s threshold effects, which can accentuate score deviations between two products with similar nutrition facts.
Additives are chemicals added to a product to change its properties. There are many such as dyes, preservatives, gelling agents or sweeteners. Some of these substances pose a health risk.
According to the various existing studies on each of the additives, each additive is assigned an assessment: no risk, limited risk, moderate risk, hazardous.
The organic nature of the product
An organic product is one that has the USDA organic seal, the Canada organic logo or the European organic label. They avoid chemical pesticides which can pose a health risk.
The rating established by the app is an opinion given by Yuka. The adjectives \"Excellent,\" \"Good,\" \"Poor\" and \"Bad\" refer to this score and not to the product directly.

This criterion represents 30% of the rating. If a hazardous additive is present, the maximum score for the product is set at 49/100. In this case, this criterion can represent more than 30% of the rating.
This criterion represents 10% of the rating.
This criterion represents 60% of the rating.

Refined salt is white because it has been chemically treated to make it white and suitable for sprinkling.
Table salt is extracted from underground salt layers through energy-intensive processes that degrade the subsoils.
Sea salt is extracted naturally, environmentally and sustainably through the evaporation of seawater in salt ponds.
With the market invasion of fake honeys diluted with sugar or water, it\'s important to check that honey is harvested and potted by the beekeeper at the address mentioned on the pot.
This honey is not directly potted by the harvesting beekeeper.
Honey harvested and potted by the beekeeper guarantees an unprocessed product.

Pollinated flowers to produce honey are likely to be contaminated by chemical pesticides used in agriculture. These pesticides will in turn contaminate the honey and endanger the bees as well as our health. We must therefore favor organic honey, which guarantees the production of honey without chemical treatment and respectful of fauna and flora. While it is difficult to define exactly where the bees have pollinated, the organic label defines the \"pollination area\" as a radius of 3 km around the hive, as bees struggle to go further.
It\'s important to choose organic honey, for health reasons and for the survival of the bees.
Good for your health and that of bees

The explosion of honey consumption has opened the market to massive imports of trafficked honey, called adulterated honeys. More often than not, these honey have been diluted with sugar syrups or water. According to tests carried out in 2015, almost a third of the honey sold in Europe would be tainted, therefore fraudulent. Asian countries, Spain and Ukraine are unfortunately known for the export of low-priced non-regulatory honeys. Products with the words \"mixture of EU and non-EU honey\" with low traceability must be left on the shelf: they do not guarantee that the honey complies with European standards which require the label \"honey\" be applied to only pure honey.
These honeys have low traceability and are likely to be diluted with sugar or water.

There is a lot of trafficked honey on the market; these are called adulterated honeys. More often than not, these honeys have been diluted with sugar syrups or water. Products with low traceability must be left on the shelf.
Honey from the European Union is less likely to be fraudulent.
Honey is made up of 80% sugar, it is to be limited in all cases. This product gets the best possible grade for a honey (60/100).

Table salt is extracted from underground salt layers through energy-intensive processes that degrade the subsoils. In contrast, sea salt is extracted naturally, environmentally and sustainably by the evaporation of seawater in salt ponds.
The extraction of table salt is much less environmentally friendly than sea salt.

Unrefined salt comes directly from the sea or land, with no transformation or chemical treatment.\10\10Unrefined salt is generally grayish and contains sodium, magnesium and other minerals. Conversely, refined salt only contains sodium because its minerals are destroyed during the refining process which aims to whiten it, make it flow and maximize its shelf life.

Refined salt is chemically treated to whiten it, make it flow and maximize its shelf life.\10\10Unfortunately, minerals such as magnesium and trace elements that make up the salt are removed during the process: only the sodium remains.

The extraction of sea salt is much more respectful of the environment.
